tei:
<pb n="200"/>
and the action that is to follow in the <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi>, both in the scene depicted and in the surrounding objects.<lb/>
The engraved initials that accompany the headpieces are simple but with a frame that echoes that of the headpiece.<lb/>
The tailpieces are more freely imaginative, representing fantastic, sometimes grotesque, creatures or decorated objects.<lb/>
Figure 2 is an example from the <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi>, Book VII, reused in <hi rend="italic">Works</hi> II, <hi rend="italic">Essay on Man</hi>, p.&nbsp;24, and <hi rend="italic">To a Lady</hi>, p.&nbsp;71.<lb/>
They are excessively splendid in the way that Kent’s decorations of aristocratic homes are splendid, and they are sometimes too big for the quarto page.<hi rend="sup">18</hi><lb/>
<head><hi rend="smallcaps">The Dunciad</hi> (1728) and <hi rend="smallcaps">The Dunciad Variorum</hi> (1729)</head><lb/>
The <hi rend="smallcaps">Dunciad</hi> in <hi rend="italic">Works</hi> (1735) seems to have been printed by 3 January 1733, a date given at the end of its mock declaration signed by John Barber.<lb/>
Although its notes were moved to the end of the volume, it was in other respects very dependent on the presentation of the <hi rend="italic">Variorum</hi> in 1729.<hi rend="sup">19</hi><lb/>
That in turn drew on the model of the <hi rend="italic">Odyssey</hi> engravings.<lb/>
Both Engel and Savage have pointed to a drawing of an owl at Chatsworth, most probably by Kent, as the basis for the owl that formed the frontispiece to the first <hi rend="smallcaps">Dunciad</hi> (1728).<hi rend="sup">20</hi><lb/>
In that frontispiece, the owl, which Engel suggests is ‘from the medieval art of heraldry’, stands on a column of books (a mockery of a Greek altar).<hi rend="sup">21</hi><lb/>
The central pillar is an extraordinarily thick volume, stamped with ‘<hi rend="smallcaps">OGILBY</hi>’ on the spine and on the front with something resembling a coat of arms.<lb/>
The allusion is to a passage in the poem on Theobald’s library that has a surprising relevance to Pope’s own books.<lb/>
He roll’d his eyes that witness’d huge dismay,<lb/>
Where yet unpawn’d, much learned lumber lay,<lb/>
Volumes, whose size the space exactly fill’d;<lb/>
Or which fond authors were so good to gild;<lb/>
Or where, by Sculpture made for ever known,<lb/>
The page admires new beauties, not its own.<lb/>
Here swells the shelf with Ogleby the great,<lb/>
There, stamp’d with arms, Newcastle shines compleat . . .<lb/>
(I.105–12, <hi rend="smallcaps">Dunciad</hi> 1728 & 1729, 29–30)<lb/>
<lb/>
<hi rend="sup">18.</hi> <hi rend="italic">William Kent: Designing Georgian Britain</hi> illustrates many objects that have something in common with the engravings: the Prince of Wales’s barge with its mermaids and dolphins (fig.&nbsp;12.1); the mermaids at the base of a settee in Wanstead House (fig.&nbsp;17.10); a figure very like Leucothea in a chandelier for the King (fig.&nbsp;19.8); mermaids at the foot of girandoles for the Leineschloss, Hanover (fig.&nbsp;19.10); putti are pervasive.<lb/>
<hi rend="sup">19.</hi> David Foxon, <hi rend="italic">English Verse, 1701–1750</hi> (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1975), gives the date of publication as 13 March 1729 (P771–2).<lb/>
<hi rend="sup">20.</hi> Published 18 May 1728 (Foxon, <hi rend="italic">English Verse</hi>, P764–5). There is a distinguished facsimile edition: <hi rend="italic">Pope’s Dunciad of 1728: A History and Facsimile</hi>, ed. David L. Vander Meulen (Charlottesville: University Press of Virginia for the Bibliographical Society of the University of Virginia, 1991).<lb/>
<hi rend="sup">21.</hi> For discussion of this frontispiece, see Engel, ‘The <hi rend="smallcaps">Dunciad</hi> Illustrations’, 164; Savage, ‘Kent as Book Illustrator’, 427.<lb/>
